Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Modular Tensioning Cartridge
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project will develop a disruptive tow tension control technology specifically designed for the unique processing variables of composite material manufacturing to solve the limiting factor of tension control the industry currently faces. In composites manufacturing multiple materials with different tensile strengths and elasticity are combined to make a stronger product, and the lack of affordable tension control has up to this point limited the speed and quality of finished products within the industry. By controlling tension there are fewer gaps, uneven tows, and breaks, resulting in higher quality end product and reduced scrap rates. The composites industry is forecasted to grow at a 7% compound annual growth rate to $10.9 billion in 2018 despite these manufacturing limitations. By removing the limiting factor of tension control it is estimated that production could expand 15%-25%, increasing the growth of this industry even further. With composites? primary and growing role in renewable energy, aerospace, construction, automobiles, pipe and tank, and consumer goods, a manufacturer?s ability to remove limitations to effectively meet demand without sacrificing quality will be critical. Expanded productivity will allow for greater innovation with composites within existing industries and promote their use in new industries.

The intellectual merit of this project centers on determining the feasibility of a Modular Tensioning Cartridge for composites manufacturing. The objectives of this project are 1) to determine if tension can be controlled near or at zero, 2) to achieve miniaturization of the unit for multiple use applications, and 3) to determine cost targets and economic feasibility. Research will be conducted to develop a load cell (sensing unit) capable of detecting minor (gram) changes in output in relation to key considerations of beam loading and sensing capability, through testing of multiple design, shape, and material combinations. Further research and testing will be conducted to discover heat dissipation requirements, fuzzing risks and solutions, and determine design and material requirements in order to achieve proper miniaturization of the full unit. Final research will be conducted to validate the economic value proposition of the unit to customers based on unit quality, size, performance, and service life in relation to cost and additional output/productivity generated. The team will determine the viability of load cell technology as a sensing device, and the combination of materials and design that will meet sizing, performance, and cost requirements.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Montalvo sought to develop new technologies and methods for detecting and controlling tension of composite tows and tapes compromised of carbon fiber. Manufacturers are struggling with process related problems, many of which could be solved with individual tension control compensation. During this research project Montalvo targeted key technologies that would be required for implementation of such a device and focused on their development. This technology has widespread applications in many carbon fiber and weaving applications, utilizing an individualized tension control system to increase productivity and increase manufacturing capability.

 To develop this technology required significant research in carbon fiber processing methods. Because of the high directional strength and extremely low resistance to shear force of carbon fiber it was critical to characterize its properties in relation to typical processing applications. These findings helped us to determine methods for handling / guiding and controlling the tows without causing damage or deterioration (such as fuzzing) to the fibers, a critical necessity of a contact based tensioning system.

Determining cost and space effective technologies for load (tension) sensing and control proved to be a challenge. It was necessary to develop a form of a load cell that met physical space limitations while also achieving reliability and performance standards that would be suitable in a high end manufacturing environment. Through our efforts we created new sensors which could meet these harsh physical demands and low tension ranges reliably and in a cost effective manner. This sensor is capable of measuring a change in tension below 1 gram, and at the same time is capable of a maximum load near 200 grams, all while maintaining a low hysteresis and with repeatability over 98%, and a robust overload safety factor. Combining this technology with existing motorized feedback control led to the development of a closed loop system that can detect and control tension at or near zero tension, allowing it to compensate for inertial and frictional effects.

To be applicable this technology had to be to miniaturized  because carbon fiber is collected in close proximity to the infeed of the process and need for hundreds (even thousands) of tows per process or application a very tight form factor was required. This added several constraints including minimum bend radius for the material, heat dissipation requirements for the enclosure and methods to reduce accumulation of broken fibers from upstream processes such as frictional guide combs and bars. To overcome these obstacles a novel contact and engagement device was created, along with a positive pressure zone that could reduce enclosure temperature and prevent nesting of carbon fiber around critical components such as the motor and load cell. This led to a device with the capability to be self cooling, and to an extent, self cleaning.

At key stages and after completion of the research it was necessary to evaluate our cost of goods position. As a manufacturer Montalvo is keenly aware of the need to produce a product that appeals to both the customer, meeting their budget requirements and also provide a suitable margin to justify the expenditure of resources to pursue this endeavor. Based on the system and components required for this it is achievable to produce this device in a precision manufacturing environment. With it this product can yield a reasonable margin, when compared with alternatives that are either excessively crude (not able to meet expectations), or exceptionally expensive (unaffordable in scale), such as servo-driven systems with PLC controls in the 10-20 tow range. This offers a reasonable value proposition to the customer or end user. Additionally it provides them with controls and systems information beyond what is ordinarily achievable in operations of production scale.
